pullRequest.title: feat(JOML): Chunks Standardization
pullRequest.bodyText:
This attempts to line up with the BlockRegions class and follows a similar pattern. I basically depreciated ChunkMath and ChunkConstants and moved those methods into a utility Chunks class. The method names are renamed to something simpler that is easier to follow, but  names are up for debate. The class name is descriptive enough without also including that into the method name. Should get the general gist of the method across.
I migrated #getEdgeRegion into BlockRegion which is a  better generalization of that implementation then constraining it to ChunkMath. I'm not sure what to do with #populateMinAdjacent2D but it seems to be mainly used for testing light propagation.
These changes would also need some testing for coverage but this is the initial implementation.

nodes.bodyText: I think assertEquals takes the expected value as first argument, and the actual value as second argument. So I think these assertion arguments should be the other way around.
I think these tests should use the chunk constants instead of hard-coded numbers.
Swap the arguments (actual vs expected) around.
We may also turn this into parameterized tests...

It is mentioned in the docstring. Probably the hidden part is that we don't offer a replacement for the exact signature but ask the caller to create a block region from center and extents:
Chunks.toChunkRegion(BlockRegions.createFromCenterAndExtents(pos, extent))
(Writing this makes me thing whether we should rename createFrom... to just from... on BlockRegions 🤔 )

nodes.bodyText:
I'm not sure this pure constants class should be deprecated. It is exactly that, a pure static class holding some constants, which are decoupled from Chunk or Chunks in general.
Only argument for merging this with ChunkMath into Chunks is that there is one file less to look at. Probably doesn't matter in the end 🤷
The chunk position is a single integer - what does this position mean?
And should this method ever be used directly (with a different chunkPower than the one from the constants)?

This method does not take any arguments to set the size of a chunk... Does this method actually do the following:

returns the position of the chunk that encompasses the given world position
